column1: === Great Fire of 1941 ===
Main article: Great Fire of 1941.Santander fell victim to a great fire in 1941. Fanned by a strong south wind
column2: the fire burned for two days. The fire started in Cádiz Street
column3: next to the harbour
column4: the Cathedral and the medieval quarter. The fire destroyed the Old Town Hall
column5: Jesús de Monasterio and Vargas streets and Atarazanas square buildings. It led to a major change in the architecture of Santander
column6: away from the older small stone and wood buildings with balconies to the enormous blocks of flats built during the reconstruction.There was only one casualty of the fire
column7: a firefighter from Madrid killed in the line of duty
column8: but thousands of families were left homeless and the city was plunged into chaos. The fire destroyed the greater part of the medieval town centre and gutted the city's Romanesque cathedral.

== Climate ==
The city of Santander has an oceanic climate (Köppen climate classification Cfb)
column2: the annual thermal oscillation of the average monthly temperatures reaching around 10 °C (18 °F).The maximum temperature reached in Santander Airport was 37.8 °C (100 °F) on 27 June 2009
column3: and the minimum temperature −5.4 °C (22 °F) on 21 January 1957. The warmest maximum daytime average for a month was in August 2003
column4: with 27.1 °C (80.8 °F). Warm months (mean above 22 °C (72 °F)) are however rare.

column1: Sunshine hours are very low by comparison with the rest of mainland and southern Spain. Even compared with other areas of northern Spain

column1: === Diet ===
Santander's cuisine is characteristic of Cantabria in that it is based mainly on seafood. Popular shellfish include almejas (clams) and navajas (razor clams); fish include seabream
column3: anchovies
column4: seabass and sardines; and squid and cuttlefish are also commonly eaten.

column1: Some typical dishes from the city of Santander are the fried calamari called rabas
column3: bean stew called cocido montañés
column4: and seafood dishes ranging from seabass and sardine to products such as morguera.
